instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2289: What is A2289? A2289 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2020 with EMC 3456, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01987..
definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2020 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi, I was to preface by saying I do not know how these newer boards work.

I had a cap that blew and I replaced it on this board, I do not have the schematics so I can not say specifically. I have attached a picture of the cap though.

Connecting this board to a USB-C meter it successfully goes to 20V, drawing about 20mA -> to about 150mA for a second -> to 450-500mA for a brief moment -> 350mA for slightly longer then back to 20mA.

I do not know if is actually working properly, the cpu does turn on during the 450-500mA phase, I do not have a whole computer to properly test it.

Do you think it is functional?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2020 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1jQm6hpWVPsn0oBCpLr-xvD_g9td_gLq0/view?usp=sharing[/URL]
No boardview available.

If the board gets stuck in 20mA, is not working properly.

Test the board alone on the desk, disconnecting LCD, trackpad, etc.
Check for USB activity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2020 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: I literally only have the board, that's why I was asking. Thank you for the schematics.
